skill.name: slo-implementation
skill.description: Define and implement Service Level Indicators (SLIs) and Service Level Objectives (SLOs) with error budgets and alerting. Use when establishing reliability targets, implementing SRE practices, or measuring service performance.
skill.summary: Define and implement Service Level Indicators (SLIs) and Service Level Objectives (SLOs) with error ...
skill.author: wshobson

security_audit.summary: This skill contains only documentation and YAML/PromQL templates. No executable code, file system access, network calls, or command execution. Purely informational content for SLO implementation guidance.

content.user_title: Define SLOs with error budgets and alerts
content.value_statement: Reliability targets are often unclear and hard to measure. This skill provides SLI, SLO, and error budget templates with alerting guidance for implementing SRE practices.
actual_capabilities: Explain SLI, SLO, and SLA hierarchy with definitions
Provide PromQL examples for availability and latency SLIs
Offer YAML templates for SLO targets and error budget policy
Define Prometheus recording rules for SLI and SLO compliance
Provide multi-window burn rate alert examples
Outline weekly, monthly, and quarterly SLO review cadence
limitations: No automated data collection or deployment capability
Assumes Prometheus and Grafana style metrics format
Does not calculate live SLOs from real-time data
Reference files like templates may not be included

use_cases.title: Set service reliability targets
use_cases.description: Define SLOs and error budgets for critical services and align teams on reliability goals.

use_cases.title: Add SLO alerts
use_cases.description: Create burn rate alerts and recording rules to detect SLO violations early.

use_cases.title: Review reliability trends
use_cases.description: Use SLO review cadence guidance to track reliability goals across releases.

prompt_templates.title: SLO basics
prompt_templates.prompt: Explain the difference between SLI, SLO, and SLA for a web API and suggest one example SLI.

prompt_templates.title: SLO target setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Propose a 99.9 percent availability SLO for an API and show a PromQL SLI expression.

prompt_templates.title: Error budget policy
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an error budget policy with actions at 50, 10, and 0 percent remaining.

prompt_templates.title: Burn rate alerts
prompt_templates.prompt: Draft multi-window burn rate alerts for a 99.9 percent availability SLO using Prometheus rules.

output_examples.input: Create an SLO plan for an API service
output: Availability SLO at 99.9 percent over 28 days
PromQL SLI ratio for successful requests calculation
Error budget policy with actions at 50, 10, and 0 percent remaining
Fast burn rate alert threshold at 14.4x over 5 minute window
Slow burn rate alert threshold at 6x over 6 hour window

best_practices: Start with user-facing services and simple SLIs that reflect user experience
Use multi-window burn rate alerts to reduce alert noise while detecting real issues
Review SLOs on a regular cadence and adjust targets based on actual performance
anti_patterns: Setting 100 percent SLOs without error budget leaves no room for innovation
Using only internal metrics that do not reflect actual user impact
Ignoring error budget status when shipping risky changes causes reliability incidents

faq.question: What platforms does this skill work with?
faq.answer: It is platform agnostic but examples use Prometheus query syntax and Grafana dashboard patterns.

faq.question: What are the limits of this skill?
faq.answer: It provides guidance and templates only, not automated SLO calculations or deployments.

faq.question: Can I integrate this with existing monitoring?
faq.answer: Yes, map the SLI formulas to your current metrics and adapt the YAML templates to your alerting system.

faq.question: Does this skill access or store my data?
faq.answer: No, it only provides static guidance and examples without any data access.

faq.question: What if my SLOs are frequently violated?
faq.answer: Consider lowering targets, refining SLIs to be more achievable, and using error budget actions to prioritize reliability work.

faq.question: How does this compare to vendor SLO tools?
faq.answer: It is a lightweight framework that complements vendor SLO products with clear definitions and implementation patterns.
